Since 1986, he has conducted interdisciplinary archaeological and paleoenvironmental research in Oaxaca, particularly on issues of power, political dynamics, landscape, and ecology

container-title: He is the author of Architecture and Power in the Prehispanic Andes: The Archaeology of Public Buildings (1996), Cultural Landscapes in the Prehispanic Andes: Archaeologies of Place (2005), The Prehistory of Home (2012), Visions of Culture: An Introduction to Anthropological Theories and Theorists
note: twenty-­three peer-­reviewed articles and book chapters, and sixty-­seven professional papers. His book, A Prehistory of South America: Cultural Diversity on the Least Known Continent is forthcoming in 2014.
title: Moore is professor of anthropology at California State University, Dominguez Hills. His research focuses on cultural landscapes, the archaeology of architecture, and human adaptations on the north coast of Peru and northern Baja California. His research has been supported by the National Science Foundation, the National Geographic Society, the Wenner-­Gren Foundation for Anthropological Research, the Getty Research Institute, and other agencies and foundations

note: His methodological approaches include spatial analyses, epigraphic studies, technological analyses, and petrographic microscopy. He received a junior fellowship from Dumbarton Oaks (2012–13).
title: Kenichiro Tsukamoto is a PhD candidate in anthropology at the University of Arizona. He has participated in archaeological projects in Mexico, Guatemala, and Japan, and since 2007 he has been the codirector of the El Palmar Archaeological Project: Urbanization of Social Space in the Maya Lowlands with Javier López Camacho (Escuela Nacional de Antropología e Historia). His research focuses on power and ideological relations, ritual performance, social change, and spatial organization

container-title: 2011) and “El Sacrificio Humano en el Suroeste de Mesoamérica” (in Nuevas Perspectivas sobre el Sacrificio Humano entre los Mexicas
note: He has held research fellowships from Dumbarton Oaks (1990), and the Center for the Advanced Study in the Visual Arts, National Gallery of Art (1998). Index
title: Javier Urcid is an associate professor of anthropology at Brandeis University. He received his PhD from Yale University in 1992. His interests include the study of ancient scripts, archaeological approaches to political systems, the social dimensions of mortuary practices, and the ritual treatment of human remains. He is the author of Zapotec Hieroglyphic Writing (2001) and The Lords of Lambityeco: Political Evolution in the Valley of Oaxaca during the Xoo Phase
Other publications include “The Written Surface as a Cultural Code
